text.p: These are significant stories in the Nigerian press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Petrol tanker drivers in the midwestern town of Warri, home to one of Nigeria's four oil refineries, have called off a strike to protest against poor treatment by security forces.

- Completion of work on a 2.1 billion naira pipeline, linking southern gas fields with industries in the commercial capital Lagos, has been rescheduled to the first quarter of 1998 from later this year.
- Experts say Nigeria would benefit more from spending some of its $6 billion foreign reserves than it does by keeping it in overseas banks.
- Operators of Very Small Aperture Terminal (VSAT) satellite communications have been told that in future they will have to work through state-run Nigerian Telecommunications Limited (NITEL).
- Movement for the Survival of Ogoni People (MOSOP) says it has nothing to do with a proposed meeting between Ogonis, the National Reconciliation Committee and Royal Dutch/Shell oil company.
- Military ruler General Sani Abacha orders the release of the 1997 capital budget. Government proposes to spend 89 billion naira on capital projects this year but so far no funds have been released.
